study_identification.author_journal_year: Elad et al., Human Brain Mapping, 2021
study_identification.title: Improving the predictive potential of diffusion MRI in schizophrenia using normative models -Towards subject-level classification

study_characteristics.study_objective: Evaluate whether individual-level deviations from normative dMRI ranges (z-score distributions across white-matter ROIs) improve subject-level classification of schizophrenia versus controls, and compare deviation-derived features across FA, FAt, and FW.

dataset_name.answer: Multi-site aggregated dataset (13 sites; dataset per Cetin-Karayumak et al., 2020)
dataset_name.reason: Methods state data were collated from 13 sites and coincide with Cetin-Karayumak et al., 2020 dataset.
dataset_name.supporting_text: dMRI data were collated from 13 different sites... The dataset used in this study coincides with the dataset utilized in the published work by (Cetin-Karayumak et al., 2020)

hc_n.reason: Methods report 512 healthy controls analyzed in the study cohort.

hc_age.answer: mean 30.15; sd 14.26; min NR; max NR
hc_age.reason: Mean and SD are reported; min and max are not stated in the paper.

hc_sex.reason: Male count/percent are provided; female computed by subtraction.

imaging_modality.reason: Study analyzes diffusion MRI metrics FA, FAt, FW.
imaging_modality.supporting_text: ...from which FA was derived... Free-water imaging model... fractional volume (FW) and tissue FA (FAt) were estimated.

analysis_level.reason: Values are computed per white-matter tract ROIs (17 tracts) plus WM skeleton average.
analysis_level.supporting_text: ...IIT ... fiber tract ROIs atlas v. 4.1 ... resulting in 17 ... complemented by white matter skeleton averaged...

preprocessing_pipeline.answer: Standardized preprocessing; retrospective harmonization across sites; FSL DTIFIT; ANTs registration; Free-water modeling; IIT WM tract atlas v4.1; WM skeleton average
preprocessing_pipeline.reason: Methods detail harmonization and software used for model fitting and registration.
preprocessing_pipeline.supporting_text: ...standardized preprocessing... harmonized across sites... FSL's DTIFIT... Free-water imaging model... registered ... using ANTs... IIT ... atlas v. 4.1 ... white matter skeleton averaged...

quality_checking.reason: Standardized preprocessing and retrospective harmonization are reported, but explicit QC metrics/thresholds and exclusion counts are not detailed here (referred to prior work).
quality_checking.supporting_text: ...standardized preprocessing protocol and were harmonized across sites... A complete account of demographics, inclusion and exclusion criteria... can be found in Cetin-Karayumak et al. (2020).

quality_checking_detail.answer: Standardized preprocessing; retrospective harmonization; no explicit QC thresholds or exclusion counts reported in this paper (referenced to Cetin-Karayumak et al., 2020).
quality_checking_detail.reason: No direct QC procedure details (e.g., motion/Euler thresholds) in the paper text; relies on referenced dataset paper.
quality_checking_detail.supporting_text: A complete account of demographics, inclusion and exclusion criteria, acquisition protocols... preprocessing and harmonization procedures can be found in Cetin-Karayumak et al. (2020).

site_effect_handling.reason: Scanner/site effects addressed with retrospective harmonization prior to modeling.
site_effect_handling.supporting_text: ...were harmonized across sites to remove site-related differences using retrospective harmonization...

site_effect_handling_detail.answer: Retrospective harmonization across 13 sites; evaluated via unpaired t-tests on matched controls; scanner-related differences removed while preserving true variability.
site_effect_handling_detail.reason: Text explains evaluation of harmonization and intent to remove scanner effects while preserving clinical variability.
site_effect_handling_detail.supporting_text: ...assess between-site differences and showed that statistical differences between matched controls across sites were removed after harmonization... These differences are important to be preserved, as they reflect true variability... while scanner related differences are removed.

model_origin.reason: Normative ranges are constructed from within-study healthy controls using kernel-weighted estimators.
model_origin.supporting_text: The normative model represents the distribution of the normative range within each ROI in the healthy controls...

model_origin_detail.answer: Within-study HC reference; sex-stratified Nadaraya–Watson kernel estimators for age-specific mean and variance; bandwidth via cross-validation.
model_origin_detail.reason: Describes sex-specific, age-weighted NW estimation and bandwidth selection.
model_origin_detail.supporting_text: ...age specific weighted mean ... and standard deviation ... for each sex separately. ... Nadaraya-Watson (NW) estimator ... bandwidth parameter ... minimized the cross-validation function...

modeling_method.answer: Nonparametric kernel regression (Nadaraya–Watson) for normative means/SDs; z-score deviations; Ridge logistic regression for classification
modeling_method.reason: NW estimator used to derive age/sex adjusted z-scores; ridge logistic used for classification.
modeling_method.supporting_text: ...Nadaraya-Watson (NW) estimator ... z-score ... We chose logistic regression with ridge regularization ...

software_tool.answer: Not reported (modeling code unspecified); imaging uses FSL and ANTs
software_tool.reason: Software tool or library for NW/logistic modeling is not specified; only imaging software is provided.
software_tool.supporting_text: FSL's DTIFIT ... ANTs registration ... (no toolkit named for statistical modeling)

response_variable.answer: FA; FAt; FW across 17 white-matter tracts and WM skeleton average
response_variable.reason: Response measures and ROIs are stated in Methods.
response_variable.supporting_text: ...mean FA, FAt and FW ... across fiber bundle ... complemented ... WM skeleton averaged FA, FAt and FW...

predictor_variables.reason: Normative model adjusts for age via kernel weighting and stratifies by sex.
predictor_variables.supporting_text: ...for each sex separately ... where x is the patient age ...

predictor_effects.answer: Sex: stratified grouping; Age: nonparametric kernel-weighted effect; Site: addressed via prior harmonization (not modeled)
predictor_effects.reason: Paper describes sex-specific models and age-weighted estimation; site handled before modeling.
predictor_effects.supporting_text: ...for each sex separately ... Nadaraya–Watson (NW) estimator ... harmonized across sites to remove site-related differences...

nm_vldtn_handle_ns.reason: Age/sex are handled in the normative model and site/scanner effects mitigated via harmonization. Other nuisance sources (e.g., motion/QC metrics, heteroscedasticity beyond NW SD) are not explicitly modeled.
nm_vldtn_handle_ns.supporting_text: ...harmonized across sites to remove site-related differences... represented ... by an age specific weighted mean ... for each sex separately.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.reason: Group comparisons and z-distribution analyses use the full cohort (non-independent within-domain evaluation).
nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.supporting_text: Group comparisons of raw dMRI values ... and z-score values ... in each ROI were ... using ... tests.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.reason: 10-fold cross-validation with normative model and bandwidth estimated only on training-fold healthy controls; performance evaluated on held-out test folds.
nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.supporting_text: Prediction performance ... validated using a 10-fold cross-validation ... the normative range, as well as the choice of a bandwidth, were estimated using only the healthy control subjects that belonged to the corresponding training set.

nm_vldtn_diff_domain.reason: No external dataset or different-domain validation reported.
nm_vldtn_diff_domain.supporting_text: No mention of external/independent datasets beyond the 13-site cohort.

clinical_dataset.answer: Multi-site aggregated dataset (13 sites; schizophrenia-spectrum and controls)
clinical_dataset.reason: Classification and analyses are performed within the same multi-site cohort.
clinical_dataset.supporting_text: ...includes 601 individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia-spectrum disorder ... and 512 healthy controls ... dMRI data were collated from 13 different sites...

diseases_studied.reason: Participants explicitly described as schizophrenia-spectrum disorder.

clinical_groups_age.answer: Schizophrenia-spectrum: mean 31.46; sd 12.31; min NR; max NR
clinical_groups_age.reason: Mean and SD reported; range not provided.

clinical_groups_sex.reason: Male count/percent provided; female computed by subtraction.

deviation_metric.answer: ROI-wise z-scores (age/sex-adjusted); extreme deviation threshold |z| > 2.999 (Bonferroni for 18 ROIs); fraction in significant z-score range from z-distribution analysis
deviation_metric.reason: Paper defines z-score computation and thresholds and derives a significant z-score range via PDF comparisons.
deviation_metric.supporting_text: The deviation ... captured by a z-score ... To define abnormal z-scores we used the threshold of |z| > 2.999 ... testing what range of FA z-scores best discriminates ... identified the range of -3.36 < z < -0.6 ...

clinical_application_and_analysis.association_analysis: Group comparisons with one-tailed Welch's t-tests and Wilcoxon rank-sum on raw and z values; classification via ridge logistic regression with 10-fold CV reporting AUC; summary measures (load, severity, mean, SD, fraction in significant range) compared with Cliff's delta.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_brief: Using complete distributions of deviation z-scores across ROIs improves schizophrenia classification over single-ROI features; combining FAt and FW z-scores achieved the best AUC (~0.73).
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_detailed: Z-scores across all ROIs improved AUC over raw values (e.g., FA z-scores all-ROI AUC = 0.67). Across modalities, all-ROI z-scores yielded AUCs: FAt 0.68, FW 0.70; combining FAt+FW z-scores reached AUC = 0.726. For FA, significant discriminatory range was -3.36 < z < -0.6 (not limited to |z|>2.999). Abnormality rates: FA infra-normal in ≥1 ROI: SZ 62/601 (10.3%) vs HC 37/512 (7.2%); FAt infra-normal: SZ 87/601 (14.47%) vs HC 38/512 (7.42%); FW supra-normal: SZ 84/601 (13.97%) vs HC 35/512 (6.8%). Summary measures showed significant group differences (e.g., average z across ROIs p<.001; Cliff's delta=0.213).
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_limitations: External (different-domain) validation absent; AUC indicates only acceptable discrimination; extreme z-score abnormalities are rare; potential residual nuisance factors (e.g., motion/QC metrics) not explicitly modeled beyond harmonization and age/sex adjustment; ROI-level approach may miss voxelwise patterns.
clinical_application_and_analysis.application_notes: Sex-stratified normative models with age-specific NW smoothing; bandwidth via CV; z-distribution used to derive a data-driven significant range; logistic ridge used to reduce overfitting; emphasizes distributed, non-localized deviations in schizophrenia.

general_notes.general_notes: Cohort coincides with Cetin-Karayumak et al., 2020 (13 sites; single-shell b=1000; post-harmonization 1.5 mm isotropic). White-matter ROI definitions from IIT Human Brain WM fiber tract atlas v4.1 (threshold 0.25) plus IIT WM skeleton average. Normative z-scores computed per ROI (17 tracts + skeleton) and modality (FA, FAt, FW).
